Baghdad . July 16
1921
Received
August 23rd 1921
Darling Father . The heat is terrific - day after day over
121 + the nights hot too. It's only the few hours before + at dawn
which give you a little reasonable feeling of coolness. Sir Percy + I
think we ought to put at the end of difficult telegrams home:
NB temp. 121.8.
On the other hand politics are running on wheels
greased with extremely well-melted grease + Sir Percy + Faisal
are scoring great triumphs. On Monday 11th the Council , at the
instance Meaning 'at the insistence of' or 'at the request of', slightly dated phrasing.
of the Naqib , rose to the fly I described to you in my
last letter even more perfectly than we could have hoped. They
unanimously declared Faisal King + charged the Ministry
of the Interior to with the necessary arrangements. I was dining
alone that night + feeling anxious - the heat makes
one not quite normal I think. You may fancy what it was
like to get to the office next morning + hear this news from
Sir Percy the moment I arrived. He added that he felt, good as
this was, that it wasn't enough + that we must have an
election by referendum to be able to prove that Faisal had the
voice of the people. With that one of Faisal's,
ADC aide-de-camp
s telephoned to
me + asked me to go round. I found him radiant - it was
very different from my first early morning visit the day after
he arrived! - but eagerly insisting on the need of a referendum
through the machinery of the Ministry of the Interior which, I
was able to assure him was exactly what Sir Percy
wanted too. Mr Cornwallis joined us + we three sat
rejoicing together for a few minutes. His anti chamber was
a sight to gladden one - full of Baghdad notables +
shaikhs Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
from all parts of the 'Iraq . The I went back
to Sir Percy to report. The thing we have been working for
seems to be in fair way to fulfilment. Sir Percy +
Faisal between them are making a new
Sharifian Term referring to things related to the Sharif (a title used to describe those - usually royal - claiming descent from the prophet Muhammad), in this case, politicians organised under Faisal, the Sharif.
party composed of all the solid moderate people, + the
old Sharifian party which raised
the revolt The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
is sinking with
an obscurity not ever decent, for it lies or will lie submerged

under the dislike + suspicion of everyone. Faisal has played
his part; he has handled his overzealous adherents with
admirable discretion. On the previous Saturday at a huge
meeting in one of the
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
independent schools, a lawyer
lately interned in Henjam, claiming to represent all the
legal profession, proclaimed him King. Faisal at once
turned him down, saying that if he had known what he
intended to say he would not have let him speak, that he
hadn't come to impose himself on the 'Iraq + that he
held to it that the people should have the opportunity of
saying whether they wanted him or not. I think he
gained more adherents by that speech than by any of
his faits et gestes since he landed to the in Basrah . The
truth is one doesn't mind what sort of crowd he
has got round him - one knows he will deal
with them rightly.
We were not, however, quite through the wood. His
more ardent adherents, egged on I think by Saiyid Mhd
Sadr (of whose pretentions Faisal is growing heartily
weary) composed a formula of allegiance in which
there was a great deal of talk of an absolutely free
+ independent 'Iraq + proceeded to circulate it
broadcast for signature. The idea was that it should
be carried out into the provinces by Baghdadis +
be signed by everyone from the paramount shaikh to the
pauper. It might have created a serious difficulty. The
provinces have the profoundest mistrust of the Baghdadis
+ very likely would have declined to sign. The Amir
Rabi'ah (head of the big
Rabi'ah Large, historically nomadic Adnanite tribe, believed to have originated in Timhamah region of Western Arabia.
tribe, a nice boy who
describes himself as "one of the household" - ie our
household) came in to me in consternation + asked

2
what this meant; he wasn't going to sign an unofficial
document in which there was no mention of our
continued presence. And on his heels came Umran al
Haji Sa'dun , head of the
Bani Hasan Several possible meanings, may refer to Beni Hassan, a Bedouin Arab tribe, or perhaps Bani Hasan, a town in Western Libya, or even Beni Hasan, an Ancient Egyptian cemetry near modern-day Minya.
(+ one of the
leaders of
the revolt The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
!) + several others, all asking
if this was our paper declaration + whether they
should sign it. It was all right: Faisal had
called up Naji Suwaidi the previous evening + told
him to stop the thing + at a conference, which had
taken place early that morning between him + Sir Percy
it had been decided that
the advisor to the Interior - dear little Mr Thomson -
should summon form a small committee at once of
people like Majid Shawi (tactfully including Naji
Suwaidi who had drawn up the unofficial
formula!) + compose an official declaration
which should be circulated through the country by
means of the
Mutasarrifs Governor of an administrative district.
, +
Qaimmaqams Governor of a provincial district.
. So I
was able to send my visitors away comforted
by telling them to wait till the real thing
appeared. Thus we rounded another corner.
Meantime a rather pretty + quite harmless
episode had occurred. The Mayor of
Mu'adhdham The location of Mu’adhdham is not certain, it may be a district of Baghdad.
summoned together all the leading townsmen +
they spontaneously swore allegiance to Faisal +
sent him a deputation to tell him so. I liked that.
It is very significant that the
Kamalists Now Kemalists, refers to the founding ideology of the Republic of Turkiye, characterised by reform and embracing of Western lifestyle. Founded by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.
, as soon
as they heard that Faisal was coming began
a hot propaganda in favour of their candidate,
Shaikh Ahmad Idrisi , the Sanusi - he hails from

the deserts west of Egypt where that tiresome
Mrs Rosita Forbes went. The first we heard of it
was when one of the citizens of Mosul brought to
Mr Nalder a document, calling to on all Iraqis to swear fealty
to the Sanusi . which It had been thrown into his courtyard.
The next news came from a gentleman called the
Naqib of Samarra who has been with the Turks
ever since 1918 + has just come in. He has a very
roguish reputation but I rather took to him. He told
me that the Turks had invited him to bring down
these allegiance papers + that he had refused,
though he mentioned others who had accepted. Sure
enough, that very day, another gentleman came
to Ja'far Pasha + produced 80 of them which he
asked Ja'far to hand over to Faisal ! The
Sanusi doesn't therefore seem to be cutting much
ice + the very thing is happening which we
desired, namely that Faisal's presence is striking
Turkish propaganda dead. There's no talk of
the Turks in the coffee shops these days; they
talk of Faisal's last speech + of whether there
will be a referendum - splendid, isn't it.
The mere fact that wild fowl like the Naqib
of Samarra are flocking in or sending messages to
Faisal to ask if they may come is very satisfactory.
It looks as if they had not much confidence in
the Turco-Sanusi scheme. Faisal deals with
these requests with the utmost propriety. He tells

3
the messengers that the outlaws who sent them
must obtain seek for pardon from
Govt Government
+ therewith
sends them in to us. I see them, get Sir Percy 's
orders, + let Faisal know that he is to send
them out to their clients + tell them to come
in + see Sir Percy. So that Faisal gets the
kudos + we retain our official decent rights!
Incidentally some of these messengers are the most
remarkable people,
'Aqail The Aquail tribe is one of many tribes within Iraq, some of which pre-date Islam. For centuries, tribes were the primary form of social organization through much of the Arabian Peninsula and tribal traditions remain culturally important in the region today.
who fought with
Mr
Lawrence
, whom I greet as friends once removed.
The office of a morning is flooded with tribal shaikhs.
Today they were sitting in rows on the ground under
the awning of the courtyard. They come up to see
Faisal + pay their respects to Sir Percy + incidentally
to me. Sometimes - mostly - what they come to
learn to whether Faisal has our support. They
hear it first from me + then from Sir Percy + I
think they go away satisfied. This week it has
been the Euphrates ; next week it will be the
Tigris . Tonight Faisal has 50 of them to dinner.
Dinners! in this weather they really are a trial.
The Coxes gave one to Faisal on Wednesday. I was
well off for I sat by Air Vice Marshall Sir Geoffrey
Salmond who has flown over from Cairo in 9
hours - says he never suffered so much as he
has in being transplanted so rapidly from the
temperate climate of Egypt to our torrid zone.
Next night, being July 14, we all had to go to a

ball given by the French consul, it being their
Day Bastille Day
. I had Major Yetts (in from Ramadi ) +
Mr Thomson to dinner first. Barring that we
were all melting it was a very amusing dinner
because they told such delightful Arab stories
one against the other. Like this one of Major
Yetts's: when a
Mutasarrif Governor of an administrative district.
was appointed
to Ramadi last January, a noted highway man
of the
Dulaim Large Sunni Arab royal tribe.
tribe came to Major Yetts +
asked whether he should oblige by terrifying
the Mutasarrif on arrival. Major Yetts thanked
him for his kind thought but said it wasn't
necessary. I think I never felt anything
like the heat at that French ball. I didn't
stay very long + while I was there I sat
outside most of the time talking to Sasun Eff
+ Sir Geoffrey . But outside was almost as
hot as inside. The French Consul has received
instructions from his
Govt Government
to pay no attention
whatever to Faisal! it will be a little
difficult for him when Faisal is King.
Next day I did something much nicer. Sir
Geoffrey came to tea with me + then carried me
off to swim with the Coxes + the Airforce. It
was heavenly. The temperature of the water must
be well over 180; you stay in till after sunset.
but don't think for a moment that it's cool after
sunset. It's about the hottest hour of the day.

4. July 17 . In the middle of the week the
Govt Government
Girls' School had a
breaking up function. Lady Cox came, at the instance, of Sir
Percy , + was very pleasant. It was quite a good function -
the usual songs + recitations on the part of the children +
crowds of proud mothers looking on. But the heat, + the
length of it! Lady Cox stayed nearly an hour + I
stayed an hour + a half - I ought to have stayed
to the end, but it wasn't in sight. The last number
that I witnessed was a domestic scene in which a large
doll was undressed, washed + put to bed, but it
didn't carry as much conviction as it should, for they
put the doll to bed wrapped up in the wet towel
they had just dried it with.
Last night I dined with one of the poor waifs who
are cast up on our shores from Persia - Qasim Khan
who was Military Governor of Tehran under Zia al
Din. I thought him a particularly nice + interesting creature
but alas! what chance is there for political enthusiasts
of that sort in Persia! The situation there is far from
reassuring. The Bolshevist minister is making a tremendous
propaganda + with Persia in the state of chaos that
it is in there's nothing which can gather itself together
+ oppose him. A Bolshevist Persia all along our East
flank won't be pleasant. Qasim Khan is married to
a Christian girl from Constantinople - she is no asset
to him, a stupid vulgar little creature; but the trouble is
that the educated Moslem will marry almost anyone
rather than a completely uneducated Moslem woman. I
shall have to ask them to dinner.
This morning I rode before breakfast with Mr Tod + the
Campbell Mackies . Even at that hour a haze of dust
+ heat was hanging over the world. We took it easily
+ didn't go far. We are swimming this evening, a large
party including Sir Geoffrey + the Coxes . It's the only

possible form of
exercise excercise
in this weather.
The Philby business is clearing up.
It has been very
horrid for me, for in their angry amazement at
having to suffer for what was entirely his own fault
they have accused me of being the cause of his dismissal
- at least she has. But I think she has thought
better of it.
She came to lunch with the Coxes and
was very pleasant, + he lunched yesterday to say
goodbye; he has gone up to Persia for a bit. We
came home together after lunch + he said he had
hopes that he might get some job here on land
settlement, but he thought he had better leave
politics alone. I should be very glad if he got
some work of that kind here. He is very capable
+ devoted to the country; he's not a man we
can afford to lose.
I've got Mother 's letter of June 19 with an enclosure
from Alice Egerton , + also your letter of June 16. I hope
the Dow. Lady Carlisle will die. I'm longing for your
comments on the
coal strike Likely refers to the 1921 coal strike, which was ended on the 28th June when the Government agreed to subsidise the coal industry.
settlement.
Your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude.

Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
ARAB BUREAU, BAGHDAD .
G L Bell
